pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw:
I believe that GetElement will create a blank element with default values if one does not exist, though this probably isn't well-documented (see [SDF.cc:729](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf_2.0/src/SDF.cc#cl-729)).

I think it won't give an empty pointer unless there's a memory allocation error, which we don't usually check for, though it may be good practice.
content.html:
I believe that GetElement will create a blank element with default values if one does not exist, though this probably isn't well-documented (see SDF.cc:729).

I think it won't give an empty pointer unless there's a memory allocation error, which we don't usually check for, though it may be good practice.

pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw: GetElement could return ther result of addElement (indeed, line SDF.cc:729). And addElement return the result of ElementPtr() ([SDF.cc:790](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf_2.0/src/SDF.cc#cl-790)) which would be an empty smart pointer. Am I missing something?
content.html: GetElement could return ther result of addElement (indeed, line SDF.cc:729). And addElement return the result of ElementPtr() (SDF.cc:790) which would be an empty smart pointer. Am I missing something?

pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw:
Ah, you are correct that it can return an empty ElementPtr if you try to get an element that doesn't have a description. This shouldn't happen for the force torque sensor since it has a element description. Here's two ways I can think of:

1. If there's an error loading sdf files or a spelling error in element name, it might not find the description.

2. For plugins element tags (e.g. [some tags for MudPlugin](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/worlds/mud.world#cl-103)), since they are not defined in sdf.

I don't think those cases will be an issue for this.
content.html:
Ah, you are correct that it can return an empty ElementPtr if you try to get an element that doesn't have a description. This shouldn't happen for the force torque sensor since it has a element description. Here's two ways I can think of:

  1. If there's an error loading sdf files or a spelling error in element name, it might not find the description.

  2. For plugins element tags (e.g. some tags for MudPlugin), since they are not defined in sdf.

I don't think those cases will be an issue for this.

pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw: Ummm I believe that your 1. point is a very valid case for an assertion. Here gazebo is using an external library (sdformat) which under weird/buggy circumstances could return an empty pointer. Anyway, up to you @traversaro, I'm fine without it.
content.html: Ummm I believe that your 1. point is a very valid case for an assertion. Here gazebo is using an external library (sdformat) which under weird/buggy circumstances could return an empty pointer. Anyway, up to you @traversaro, I'm fine without it.

pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw:
Just a stupid question, as no sensor offset has been added in the tests and I want to double check operator+ semantics for Pose objects: 
for gazebo::math::Pose objects A and B, operator+ is defined such that B+A == A*B?
content.html: Just a stupid question, as no sensor offset has been added in the tests and I want to double check operator+ semantics for Pose objects: for gazebo::math::Pose objects A and B, operator+ is defined such that B+A == A*B?

pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw:
~~The Pose class doesn't overload the `*` operator~~, though the Quaternion does. I use Pose much more often than Quaternion, so I wrote it as `B+A`. I would have to reread the Quaternion documentation to figure out the proper syntax.

You have two good points, though, that there are multiple ways of expressing this math, and that we don't test the interpretation of the sensor `pose` tag.

EDIT: I'm thinking about how to update the test.
content.html:
The Pose class doesn't overload the * operator, though the Quaternion does. I use Pose much more often than Quaternion, so I wrote it as B+A. I would have to reread the Quaternion documentation to figure out the proper syntax.

You have two good points, though, that there are multiple ways of expressing this math, and that we don't test the interpretation of the sensor pose tag.

EDIT: I'm thinking about how to update the test.

pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw: I am probably missing something: apparently from the documentation ( http://gazebosim.org/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1math_1_1Pose.html#a7ce5d2d36f931b7af4eaeefa0c101060 ) the `Pose` class overloads the `*` operator.
content.html: I am probably missing something: apparently from the documentation ( http://gazebosim.org/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1math_1_1Pose.html#a7ce5d2d36f931b7af4eaeefa0c101060 ) the Pose class overloads the * operator.

pullrequest.title: Add proper flexibility to force_torque sensor specification, solving issue #940

content.raw:
To redeem my embarrassment, I have a simple patch to test the sensor pose offset:
~~~
diff -r 32eaae1c2181 test/worlds/force_torque_frame_test.world
--- a/test/worlds/force_torque_frame_test.world	Sun May 04 01:36:34 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/worlds/force_torque_frame_test.world	Mon May 05 14:08:29 2014 -0700
@@ -166,7 +166,7 @@
         <parent>link_1</parent>
         <child>link_2</child>
         <!-- joint_12 at the interface between the two cylinders -->
-        <pose>0 -10 0 0 -1.5708 0</pose>
+        <pose>0 -10 0 0 -0.7854 0</pose>
         <axis>
           <limit>
             <lower>-0.0</lower>
@@ -217,6 +217,7 @@
           </force_torque>
         </sensor>
         <sensor name="force_torque_12_sensor_and_parent_to_child" type="force_torque">
+          <pose>0 0 0 0 -0.7854 0</pose>
           <always_on>true</always_on>
           <visualize>true</visualize>
           <update_rate>1000</update_rate>
@@ -226,6 +227,7 @@
           </force_torque>
         </sensor>
         <sensor name="force_torque_12_sensor_and_child_to_parent" type="force_torque">
+          <pose>0 0 0 0 -0.7854 0</pose>
           <always_on>true</always_on>
           <visualize>true</visualize>
           <update_rate>1000</update_rate>
~~~
content.html:
To redeem my embarrassment, I have a simple patch to test the sensor pose offset:

diff -r 32eaae1c2181 test/worlds/force_torque_frame_test.world
--- a/test/worlds/force_torque_frame_test.world Sun May 04 01:36:34 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/worlds/force_torque_frame_test.world Mon May 05 14:08:29 2014 -0700
@@ -166,7 +166,7 @@
         <parent>link_1</parent>
         <child>link_2</child>
         <!-- joint_12 at the interface between the two cylinders -->
-        <pose>0 -10 0 0 -1.5708 0</pose>
+        <pose>0 -10 0 0 -0.7854 0</pose>
         <axis>
           <limit>
             <lower>-0.0</lower>
@@ -217,6 +217,7 @@
           </force_torque>
         </sensor>
         <sensor name="force_torque_12_sensor_and_parent_to_child" type="force_torque">
+          <pose>0 0 0 0 -0.7854 0</pose>
           <always_on>true</always_on>
           <visualize>true</visualize>
           <update_rate>1000</update_rate>
@@ -226,6 +227,7 @@
           </force_torque>
         </sensor>
         <sensor name="force_torque_12_sensor_and_child_to_parent" type="force_torque">
+          <pose>0 0 0 0 -0.7854 0</pose>
           <always_on>true</always_on>
           <visualize>true</visualize>
           <update_rate>1000</update_rate>
